Award.AwardTitle: NSF INCLUDES: Building Diverse and Integrative STEM Continua Using Socio-environmental Systems In and Out of Neighborhoods (DISCUSSION)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Lead Proposal ID: HRD 16-1649263
Principal Investigator: Gregory D Goins
Lead Institution: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
Proposal Title: Building Diverse and Integrative STEM Continua Using Socio-environmental Systems In and Out of Neighborhoods (DISCUSSION)

Collaborative Proposal ID: 16-49255
Principal Investigator: Caesar Jackson
Institution: North Carolina Central University

This collaboration between two Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) will form a networked improvement community located within the Piedmont Region of North Carolina. In close partnership with community colleges and civic organizations, the project will reach families and students that lead to broader participation of underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. The overall goal is to build and sustain a scalable, inquiry-based network with the purpose of increasing the academic success of underrepresented ethnic minorities and women in the STEM continuum. By engaging in culturally relevant socio-environmental frameworks, project outcomes will positively impact student retention, knowledge, and quantitative skills in STEM across socio-economic divides and STEM disciplines.

The Launch Pilot phase will focus on evidence-based teaching and learning approaches for middle school students. The core structure of the network will serve as a platform to launch and guide other age- and level-specific educational instruction, research, and assessment initiatives. Student understanding of the nature of science will be enhanced by adapting structure, behavior, and function (SBF) theory and system thinking hierarchical (STH) models. Ultimately, the network will represent a driver for social innovation that positively impacts broadening participation in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Diverse and Integrative STEM Continua Using Socio-environmental Systems In and Out of Neighborhoods (DISCUSSION) Networked improvement community (NIC) was assembled by two large historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs), North Carolina A&T State University (NCAT) and North Carolina Central University (NCCU).  This NIC was motivated by a need to connect underrepresented minority families to opportunities in STEM conceptual spaces.  The DISCUSSION NIC worked in close partnership with low-income neighborhoods and near-by community colleges and other community-based organizations.  The overall aim of the DISCUSSION NIC was to increase the number of prepared, motivated underrepresented minority students attaining careers in STEM.  The Food-Energy-Water Nexus emerged as a framework to create, connect, and sustain an integrated low-cost training environment for communities.  The DISCUSSION core team developed an outcome-driven process of science learning using Food, Energy Water Nexus Learning Modules (FEWLMs).  The FEWLMs consists of learning module tools for communities to help children better understand the interplay between natural systems and the human dimensions. This pilot focused on the NIC development and implementation of food, energy, and water nexus learning modules (FEWLM) curricula.  A total of 100 underrepresented minority youth engaged in science inquiry using the FEWLM curricula, including the Boys and Girls Club of Durham and Orange Counties, afterschool programs, and a 4-week program between March and April for each year of the project.  The NCA&T/NCCU DISCUSSION 'Hydrophonics' STEM Enrichment Summer Camp for middle school youth were assessed about their attitudes regarding science, educational background, and career ambitions using a modified version of the pre/post Assessing Women and Men in Engineering (AWE) Pre-College Science Activity Survey.  The DISCUSSION NIC addressed the issue of access by lowering socio-economic barriers that limit participation in STEM for underrepresented minority communities.  This was accomplished by uncovering ?real world? problem-solving while increasing youth interest and confidence to participate in STEM.  The results showed that FEWLM was an effective and affordable tool for building a NIC that positively promoted scientific literacy and quantitative skills to broaden the participation in STEM for elementary and middle school youth.  The initial cost to implement 6 FEWLM activities is less than $300 for a class size of 30 students. Furthermore, costs decreased in the subsequent years because several materials can be reused and recycled.  Therefore, this NIC stands as a blueprint to help communities expose youth who might otherwise have disregarded potential research in STEM careers.  Overall, this INCLUDES pilot represented a promising, transdisciplinary strategy to connect low-cost inquiry-based science to families, educators, and community partners in both informal and formal contexts.
